3rd party apps running their own appviews kinda makes sense but it'd be a bit weird for mutes to be per-app. I wonder if there's a plan to be able to sync private state between separate appviews run by different parties

but also important note that this is "private data" - ie data that is really only meaningful to the user themselves - not "selectively shared data" which is what people think of with like private twitter accounts or groups

that one's harder 😅

possibly doing some smart stuff by sharing state of synced relevant private data through http headers

but the basic idea is that the pds stores private state generically (with similar collection semantics to public data) & users authorize other schema-aware services to access & apply it

Paul prolly has a lot of smart ideas about it but yeah. Syncing with the PDS often for that data would probably be prohibitively expensive on the side of the PDS and/or the third party though. We solve it by having the PDS push mutes/etc to our appview directly but it’s not very clean.

3rd party apps running their own appviews kinda makes sense but it'd be a bit weird for mutes to be per-app. I wonder if there's a plan to be able to sync private state between separate appviews run by different parties

This will basically be the thing that proves the federated PDS model with an aggregated global view can actually scale to hundreds of millions of users without being prohibitively expensive and requiring hundreds of millions of dollars to operate. Horizontally scalable, low cost, high perf infra.

Tbh I’m more excited about launching the v2 AppView. The whole team has been using it for like 3-4 days now and we’re gonna yeet users onto it today. That might be why I woke up at 3AM and can’t fall back asleep lol. 2-3 months of work paying off this week hopefully.

I send all requests my PDS, i.e. putRecord and getList.

yeah your DID is your permanent identifier

you can recreate a new account at a different DID, and important your posts/likes/profile/etc. But all backlinks to your old account will be broken (follows, likes, replies, etc)

All the references to your posts in other people's repos are going to be to your did:plc DID. There's no way to update those. So migrating DIDs isn't really an option. Copying your data is doable though.

But @dholms.xyz may have something more to say, being the real expert here.

great writeup from @jaz.bsky.social 

lots of "!!!!!" and "🔥🔥🔥" in slack last night as we broke through these bottlenecks

value.text:
I wrote up a blog post on our findings with scaling Go to 192 cores per machine and the limits we ran into with the Go runtime here: jazco.dev/2024/01/10/g...

It was a really interesting problem to investigate and had us scratching our heads for a little bit but the performance gains are huge.

external.description: When running on baremetal, however, we found two key limitations of the Go runtime so far: Systems with a lot of RAM can have a lot of allocations, prompting the Go Garbage Collector to aggressively s...
external.title: Scaling Golang to 192 Cores with Heavy I/O

external.description: When running on baremetal, however, we found two key limitations of the Go runtime so far: Systems with a lot of RAM can have a lot of allocations, prompting the Go Garbage Collector to aggressively s...
external.title: Scaling Golang to 192 Cores with Heavy I/O

value.text:
Things i did not expect would ever be a problem when writing @ scale software in Go:

Go's runtime only scales well to a certain number of cores and memory size.

Especially for I/O heavy apps, Go's EPoll buffer size is small enough that you end up burning 80% of your CPU waiting on EPoll syscalls.

record.text:
ah that's a good call out! 

that's likely a historical artifact since the key material in did documents used to be uncompressed but the did-key representation is compressed

now that did docs use the compressed multikey, we can probably do away with it

Hi @dholms.xyz! What is the purpose on decompress-compress round trip in AtprotoData in Multikey type? Key is decompressed in crypto.parseMultikey and then compressed again in crypto.formatDidKey. Why?

Hi @dholms.xyz! What is the purpose on decompress-compress round trip in AtprotoData in Multikey type? Key is decompressed in crypto.parseMultikey and then compressed again in crypto.formatDidKey. Why?

Our v2 infrastructure for the AppView is coming along nicely and I'm excited to begin rolling it out (hopefully) soon to help the network scale further, faster.

record.text:
yeah node width 4 consistently gave us the smallest proof size in benchmarks

hmmm how do you mean cache locality? MST is primarily a self-authenticating sync mechanism so it's geared towards structural sharing of proofs. most views are constructed off secondary indices of record data

Interestingly though, you tuned the node width from 16 to 4, so that is not very far from a binary search tree. So I don't think you are putting too much weight on cache locality, I assume because data is mostly consumed in the AppView with normal database (not MST).

record.text: MST has same space/time complexity as prefix trie. but is better at uniformly distributing keys with similar prefixes that would otherwise clump up. also much more easily tunable for node width 👌

MST wasn't a historical accident. atproto repos are a generic record store (not just bsky) and we want similar content to live next to itself so they share proofs (bsky posts next to other bsky posts, likes next to likes, content for another app next to itself)

record.text: MST wasn't a historical accident. atproto repos are a generic record store (not just bsky) and we want similar content to live next to itself so they share proofs (bsky posts next to other bsky posts, likes next to likes, content for another app next to itself)

Protocols that already knew it is not a general key-value store, went full-in on monotonic ids with a Prefix Trie (see Farcaster).

Regardless, a general purpose key-value store that is still good for sync, shouldn't use that much nodes data, but I might be wrong, I need to test.

record.text:
🎉 The Bluesky network is now 3M users and thriving! 🎉

More confident than ever that we users will be able to control the internet going forward. Which will make it possible to fix the problems caused by the misaligned incentives that have caused us so many problems.

More big things coming soon!
